text:
e="preserve">Tyka Evene Nelson (born May 18, 1960) is an American singer. She is the daughter of jazz musician John L. Nelson (1916–2001) and Mattie Della Shaw (1933–2002), and the younger sister of Prince (1958–2016).
She has released four albums, and reached No. 33 on the "Billboard"s Hip-Hop Songs chart in July 1988 with "Marc Anthony's Tune", produced by Larry Graham.
Nelson is married to Maurice Phillips. She has six children.
She accepted Prince's American Music Award for Top Soundtrack following his death in 2016.
Early life.
Tyka Evene Nelson was born on May 18, 1960 in Minneapolis, Minnesota, the daughter of Mattie Della Nelson ("née" Shaw; 1933–2002) and John Lewis Nelson (1916–2001). Her parents were both African-American and her family ancestry is centered in Louisiana, and all four of her grandparents hailing from that state. Her father was a jazz pianist and songwriter, and her mother was a jazz singer. Her brother Prince Rogers was born on June 7, 1958. Both siblings developed a keen interest in music, which was encouraged by their father. According to a 2008 interview with "City Pages", she began writing songs when she was 10 and “hasn’t collaborated” with her brother since they were young.
Tyka studied and graduated at of Minneapolis’ North High
Career.
in 1978, After graduating from North High of Minneapolis, Tyka went to California where she would begin her musical career, releasing her first studio album Royal Blue in 1988, signed by Cooltempo. supporting by the songs "L.O.V.E.", “Royal Blue” and “Marc Anthony's Tune” the latter reached No. 33 on the "Billboard"s Hip-Hop Songs chart in July. the album was a failure comercial
